Hello {first_name, "there"},

I'm back at it after a nice, long bank holiday weekend with the family. There's lots of media news to catch-up on in the coming days, so there might be a few more posts that normal. 

Substack seems to be becoming the new Facebook, in that it's the site we can barely avoid writing about at the moment. So, it seems apt that we kick off with some news that involves both of them…

Substack started a local project, now FB moves in with $5m . Some local independent writers (those not in newsrooms) and their communities will hopefully benefit. But note that this is an incentivized fragmentation of the structure of local news. Platform-designed infrastructure https://t.co/RJ8C99DouO

— emily bell (@emilybell) April 29, 2021

metadata.title: Facebook to pay $5 mln to local journalists in newsletter push
metadata.description: Facebook Inc said Thursday it will give $5 million to pay local journalists in multi-year deals as part of its new publishing platform to help independent writers attract an audience and make money through the social media network.
metadata.author: Sheila Dang

metadata.title: WSJ.com Turns 25
metadata.description: Over 25 years, The Wall Street Journal has delivered news to readers in innovative ways that match the evolution of the internet. Here are some of WSJ.com’s milestones and a few name changes along the way. WSJIE, anyone?

However, as a careful reading of the above quote will show, this is not a completely altruistic move (any more than Substack's is). Facebook

you to use its tools as part of the deal. As always, I have questions about how portable Facebook-based subscriptions will be, and I'd always recommend that people take this money with their eyes firmly open to the degree to which it ties them a singular platform.

That said, the local news ecosystem generally needs innovation and experimentation, and if this initiative helps facilitate that, well, good. And, as many YouTubers have proved down the years, you might start off with a revenue stream built around a single platform, but once you have an audience, you can diversify.

Does anyone remember the phrase “new media”? I do — but then, I was a few years into my career when the first newspaper websites started appearing.

I recall being in a meeting in 1996 to talk about our publishers' internet strategy, when one of the senior people in the company came in, and railroaded the whole discussion because he'd just read somewhere that “the
net is going to be more important than the internet!”. And so began a diversion that meant that the company in question missed the web boat. Most of its titles no longer exist.
